artWork.name: Les Deux Fridas
artWork.description: Les Deux Fridas is a double self-portrait that illustrates the duality of Frida Kahlo's identity, depicting her two personas: one dressed in traditional Mexican attire and the other in a European-style dress. The painting symbolizes her emotional turmoil following her divorce from Diego Rivera.

artWork.name: Henry Ford Hospital (1932)
artWork.description: In this powerful and intimate painting, Frida Kahlo depicts herself lying naked in Henry Ford Hospital after experiencing a miscarriage. Surrounded by symbols of her loss, including a male fetus and various objects representing her pain, the artwork reflects her emotional turmoil and the physical suffering she endured during her pregnancy.

artWork.name: Autoportrait avec collier d'épines et colibri (1940)
artWork.description: This self-portrait features Frida Kahlo adorned with a thorn necklace, symbolizing her pain and suffering. A lifeless hummingbird hangs from the necklace, while a monkey and a black cat accompany her, adding layers of meaning related to love, luck, and personal turmoil.

artWork.name: La Colonne brisée (1944)
artWork.description: This oil painting depicts Frida Kahlo with a fragmented ionic column representing her spine, which has been injured from a bus accident. The artist's body is adorned with nails, symbolizing her physical and emotional pain, while tears flow down her face, reflecting her suffering.

artWork.name: Le Suicide de Dorothy Hale (1939)
artWork.description: This painting depicts the tragic suicide of Dorothy Hale, illustrating her falling from a window while simultaneously lying on the bloody pavement below. The work serves as a poignant commentary on despair and the struggles faced by women, reflecting Kahlo's own emotional turmoil.

artWork.name: Autoportrait avec la chevelure défaite (1947)
artWork.description: In this self-portrait, Frida Kahlo depicts herself with disheveled hair, symbolizing her emotional turmoil and vulnerability. The painting reflects her struggles with identity and love, showcasing her unique style and deep connection to her Mexican heritage.

artWork.name: La Casa Azul (1931)
artWork.description: La Casa Azul, or The Blue House, is the birthplace and home of Frida Kahlo. This historic house museum showcases her life, art, and personal belongings, reflecting her deep connection to Mexican culture. The house features vibrant blue walls and a rich collection of folk art, pre-Hispanic pieces, and personal artifacts.

artWork.name: Autoportrait en pleurs (1937)
artWork.description: In this poignant self-portrait, Frida Kahlo depicts herself in tears, reflecting her emotional turmoil and struggles with love and identity. The painting captures her raw vulnerability and pain, symbolizing her complex relationship with Diego Rivera and her own physical suffering.

artWork.name: Les Fruits de la Terre (1938)
artWork.description: Les Fruits de la Terre is a vibrant still life that reflects Frida Kahlo's connection to her Mexican heritage. The painting features an array of colorful fruits, symbolizing fertility and life, juxtaposed with elements that represent her personal struggles and the duality of existence. This work was created shortly before her death and serves as a poignant reflection of her experiences.

artWork.name: La Victoire (1944)
artWork.description: La Victoire is a powerful expression of Frida Kahlo's resilience in the face of suffering. The painting symbolizes her struggle and triumph over physical and emotional pain, reflecting her complex relationship with identity and femininity. It showcases vibrant colors and elements that represent her personal battles and victories.

artWork.name: La Nuit étoilée
artWork.description: A swirling night sky filled with stars over a quiet village, showcasing van Gogh's unique brushwork and emotional intensity.

artWork.name: Les Tournesols
artWork.description: A vibrant still life featuring sunflowers in a vase, celebrated for its bold colors and dynamic composition.

artWork.name: La Chambre de Van Gogh à Arles
artWork.description: An intimate depiction of Van Gogh's bedroom in Arles, characterized by its bright colors and expressive lines.

artWork.name: Autoportrait
artWork.description: A self-portrait showcasing Van Gogh's emotional state during his time in the asylum, using bold colors and brushstrokes.

artWork.name: Vincent's Chair with Pipe
artWork.description: A still life painting of Vincent's chair with a pipe resting on it, symbolizing his presence even in absence.

artWork.name: Le Semeur
artWork.description: A depiction of a sower in a field, capturing the essence of rural life and the cycle of nature.

artWork.name: Les Irises
artWork.description: A vibrant portrayal of irises in full bloom, showcasing Van Gogh's expressive use of color and texture.

artWork.name: Filles de joie
artWork.description: An exploration of the lives of women in Arles, capturing their essence through vibrant colors and emotional depth.

artWork.name: L'Autoportrait à l'oreille bandée
artWork.description: A self-portrait depicting Van Gogh after his infamous ear injury, reflecting his emotional state.

artWork.name: Les Demoiselles d'Avignon
artWork.description: Considered one of the most significant works in modern art, this painting depicts five women in a disjointed, abstract style that challenges traditional representation.

artWork.name: La Vigne rouge
artWork.description: A landscape painting featuring red vines in autumn, reflecting Van Gogh's fascination with nature's colors.

artWork.name: Guernica
artWork.description: A powerful political statement, this mural depicts the horrors of war and suffering, specifically referencing the bombing of Guernica during the Spanish Civil War.

artWork.name: La Vie
artWork.description: A complex composition exploring themes of life and death, featuring a naked couple and a child, reflecting Picasso's Blue Period.

artWork.name: Le Vieil Guitariste
artWork.description: This poignant work depicts an old blind guitarist, representing poverty and despair during Picasso's Blue Period.

artWork.name: Femme au chapeau
artWork.description: A vibrant portrait of Picasso's muse, Gertrude Stein, showcasing bold colors and expressive brushwork characteristic of Fauvism.

artWork.name: Les Trois Musiciens
artWork.description: A large-scale composition depicting three musicians in a cubist style, emphasizing geometric shapes and flat planes.

artWork.name: La Guerre et la Paix
artWork.description: A monumental mural symbolizing the contrast between war and peace through vivid imagery and powerful symbolism.

artWork.name: L'Atelier
artWork.description: An introspective look into Picasso's creative space, filled with symbolic references to his artistic journey.

artWork.name: La Maternité
artWork.description: A tender portrayal of motherhood reflecting love and care during Picasso's early artistic exploration.

artWork.name: Nude, Green Leaves and Bust
artWork.description: An intimate depiction of a nude woman alongside a bust sculpture, showcasing Picasso's exploration of form and color.

artWork.name: La Joconde (Mona Lisa)
artWork.description: La Joconde, also known as Mona Lisa, is one of the most famous paintings in the world, depicting Lisa Gherardini with an enigmatic expression. The painting is renowned for its sophisticated use of sfumato and atmospheric perspective.

artWork.name: La Cène
artWork.description: The Last Supper depicts the moment Jesus announces that one of his disciples will betray him. This mural is celebrated for its composition and emotional depth.

artWork.name: L'Homme de Vitruve
artWork.description: A drawing that illustrates the proportions of the human body according to Vitruvius, symbolizing the blend of art and science during the Renaissance.

artWork.name: L'Annonciation
artWork.description: This early work depicts the Annunciation of the Virgin Mary by the Angel Gabriel, showcasing Leonardo's mastery of light and shadow.

artWork.name: La Vierge aux rochers
artWork.description: A masterpiece depicting the Virgin Mary with the Christ Child and John the Baptist in a rocky landscape, illustrating Leonardo's innovative use of composition.

artWork.name: La Vierge et l'Enfant avec sainte Anne
artWork.description: This painting shows Saint Anne with the Virgin Mary and the Christ Child, emphasizing familial bonds and maternal love.

artWork.name: Saint Jean Baptiste
artWork.description: A late masterpiece depicting Saint John the Baptist in a dark background with a gesture that suggests both mystery and invitation.

artWork.name: Madonna Litta (c. 1490)
artWork.description: Madonna Litta depicts the Virgin Mary breastfeeding the Christ child in a dark interior setting. The painting features significant symbolism, including a goldfinch held by Jesus, representing his impending Passion, and Mary's blue mantle symbolizing the Church. The work has been attributed to Leonardo da Vinci, though some scholars debate the involvement of his pupils.

artWork.name: Le Baptême du Christ (1472-1475)
artWork.description: Le Baptême du Christ est une œuvre majeure représentant saint Jean Baptiste donnant le baptême au Christ dans les eaux du Jourdain. Le tableau, commencé par Verrocchio et achevé par Léonard de Vinci, se distingue par sa composition dynamique et son utilisation innovante de la lumière et de l'ombre.

artWork.name: La Belle Ferronnière (c. 1490)
artWork.description: La Belle Ferronnière is a portrait of an unknown woman, attributed to Leonardo da Vinci. The painting features a lady adorned with a ferronnière, a type of headband, and is characterized by its soft lighting and detailed rendering. It is believed to have been painted in Milan during the late 15th century and is currently housed in the Louvre Museum.

artWork.name: Cmon - Pop Revolution
comments: A bold commentary on modern society.
artWork.description: A vibrant piece showcasing the fusion of consumerism and culture.

artWork.name: Cmon - Neon Nights
comments: A glowing tribute to neon lights and city life.
artWork.description: This artwork radiates with electric colors, capturing urban energy.

artWork.name: Cmon - Iconic Reboot
comments: Reimagining iconic figures through modern lenses.
artWork.description: A contemporary reworking of classic pop culture symbols.

artWork.name: Marie G - Color Burst
comments: Exploring the emotional impact of color.
artWork.description: An explosion of colors designed to evoke intense feelings.

artWork.name: Marie G - Digital Echoes
comments: A tribute to the digital age.
artWork.description: Melding traditional painting with digital aesthetics.

artWork.name: Marie G - Pop Rewind
comments: A look back at the vibrant 90s era.
artWork.description: A nostalgic dive into the 90s pop culture.

artWork.name: Novarino Fabien - Urban Pop
comments: A contemporary take on street art.
artWork.description: Capturing the grit and glam of urban street culture.

artWork.name: Novarino Fabien - Chromatic Clash
comments: A bold clash of colors and urban influences.
artWork.description: Vibrant contrasts that speak to the power of visual stimulation.

artWork.name: Novarino Fabien - Pop Faces
comments: Exploring the idea of celebrity in pop culture.
artWork.description: Famous faces reinterpreted in the style of pop art.

artWork.name: Novarino Fabien - Neon Dreams
comments: A mesmerizing vision of neon lights and pop culture.
artWork.description: Neon colors bring iconic symbols to life in this dynamic piece.
